subject: Re: [junit] Including test cases with production code
msgSnippet: ... I d rather my professional image reflect that I deliver working software that s demonstrable with a suite of tests. Another option to the versioning issue
messageBody:
Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>
> I won't give the test cases to provide a documentation to a Java API (for non open source projects) for several reasons:
>

> For you:
> - as a professional and for your image you want certainly to maintain your test code in sync with the latest version of JUnit -> increases the work for an already tested production code (or would you ship test code only runnable with JUnit 3.2 ?)


I'd rather my professional image reflect that I deliver working software
that's demonstrable with a suite of tests.

Another option to the versioning issue is to distribute a baselined
version of junit.jar.

> - the test code is generally not so well written (comments...) But you are maybe an exception, but I'm not :-)


Really? If anything I'd think that the tests should be more well
written, not just for the customer, but for the product team evolving
the software. The tests document the intended use of the API, and good
tests will tell you much more about the software than studying the API
out of context.


> - you don't handle exceptions and errors in your test cases like you should treat them in a real application
>


Actually, testing for expected exceptions may provide better
documentation as to what action should be taken when the software is
integrated into a real application. In other words, by providing a test
method that enumerates and tests for possible exceptions raised by the
API you are effectively documenting the exception handling.


> For the customer:
> - if JUnit is not provided, he has to install the _right_ version if he wants to run the tests


Agreed, although there are options for distributing JUnit. Also, as
JUnit becomes more pervasive, I think this becomes moot.


> - what if the customer doesn't know JUnit at all? Will he understand the test cases, asserts, test suites (...) concepts immediatly?


This is certainly a valid point. However, one could argue that learning
JUnit is easier than learning the structure of vendor-specific examples.

> - what if the customer installs JUnit, runs your tests and get a "ClassCastException" because he didn't overwrite the excluded.properties file?
> - and so on...
>


OK, there may be general installation issues that we can't predict, but
we can document common problems.

> Instead of test cases, I would simply write a client application that uses the product's API. It's the best proof that the API can be used in a real application. The customer can start from this example to make his own application. Everybody did that, isn't it?
>


Indeed, this is the common approach. I'm simply suggesting that JUnit
tests may be more beneficial in their ability to automatically check
results and their well-defined structure and composability. I've often
run example client applications that did something (at least I assumed
so by all the console messages), but I'm not quite sure if it was correct.


>>their storage and bandwidth penalties.
>>
>
> It's not a storage or bandwidth problem. It's about how you want to communicate with your customers.
>


I want to communicate to my customers that what I've delivered to them
works, that there are measures in place to verify that it continues to
work, and that they can learn how to communicate with it using concrete
examples. Unit tests seem to be the most effective way to achieve this.

Mike
